data.enText: strode

before.enText: not used in the perfect tenses

data.enText: to walk with long steps in a particular direction

data.chText: 我们大步流星地穿过雪封的旷野。
data.enText: We strode across the snowy fields.

data.chText: 她大步走上前来迎接我。
data.enText: She came striding along to meet me.
one long step; the distance covered by a step

data.chText: 他两大步跨到屋子另一头。
data.enText: He crossed the room in two strides.

data.chText: 我正一步步赶上其他运动员。
data.enText: I was gaining on the other runners with every stride .
your way of walking or running

data.chText: 他那熟悉而坚定的步伐
data.enText: his familiar purposeful stride

data.chText: 她没有放慢脚步，径直走到我们面前。
data.enText: She did not slow her stride until she was face to face with us.
an improvement in the way sth is developing

data.chText: 在探索治疗办法方面，我们正不断取得重大进展。
data.enText: We're making great strides in the search for a cure.
trousers/pants
get into your stride
hit (your) stride

data.chText: 进入状态；开始顺利地做某事
data.enText: to begin to do sth with confidence and at a good speed after a slow, uncertain start
put sb off their stride
to make sb take their attention off what they are doing and stop doing it so well
(match sb) stride for stride
to keep doing sth as well as sb else, even though they keep making it harder for you
take sth in your stride
take sth in stride
to accept and deal with sth difficult without letting it worry you too much
without breaking stride
without stopping what you are doing

simple_means.memory_skill: strid 竞争 + e → 走路如竞赛 → 大踏步走

ex.chText: 我们骑马还是步行?
ex.enText: Shall we ride or walk?

ex.chText: 她一直走到这条小路的尽头。
ex.enText: She walked as far as the end of the path.

ex.chText: 那个男孩告诉我应该往东走。
ex.enText: The boy told me that I should walk eastward.

synonyms.bx: 指行走的最普通用词，通常后接副词或介词。

ex.chText: 我发现他在办公室里踱来踱去。
ex.enText: I found him pacing in his office.

ex.chText: 经理在屋子里来回踱步，试图找出解决问题的办法。
ex.enText: The manager paced the floor as he tried to find a solution to the problem.

ex.chText: 老虎在笼子里走来走去。
ex.enText: The tiger paced in its cage.

synonyms.bx: 尤指因紧张、担忧、不耐烦等而来回踱步。

ex.chText: 可怜的老妇人吃力地走着，几乎都抬不动脚了。
ex.enText: The poor old woman plodded along, hardly able to lift each foot.

ex.chText: 约翰继续艰难跋涉。
ex.enText: John kept plodding on.

ex.chText: 我们不得不迈着疲倦的步子继续登山。
ex.enText: We had to plod wearily on up the hill.

synonyms.bx: 指脚步缓慢、步履艰难地行走。

ex.chText: 他蹒跚地向大门走去，伤口流着血。
ex.enText: He staggered to the gate, bleeding from his wounds.

ex.chText: 那个醉鬼摇摇晃晃地往家走去。
ex.enText: The drunken man staggered home.

ex.chText: 他摇摇晃晃地站起来。
ex.enText: He staggered to his feet.

synonyms.bx: 通常指因虚弱、负重、醉酒等而导致身体失去平衡或行走失态，强调不稳定性和失控性。

ex.chText: 她转身迈着大步走了。
ex.enText: She turned and strode off.

ex.chText: 他大踏步地向他的车走去。
ex.enText: He strode towards his car.

ex.chText: 他拔腿往回走，步子又大又快。
ex.enText: He started back, striding swiftly.

synonyms.bx: 强调步子大而有力，往往伴有或显露出匆忙、自傲、精力充沛等状态。

ex.chText: 她的宝宝刚会走道儿。
ex.enText: Her baby has just learned to toddle.

ex.chText: 我两岁的儿子摇摇摆摆地走进卧室。
ex.enText: My two-year-old son toddled into the bedroom.

synonyms.bx: 特指幼儿因学步而摇摇晃晃地小步行走。

ex.chText: 那位老人摇摇晃晃地好不容易回到了座位上。
ex.enText: The old man managed to totter back to his seat.

ex.chText: 幼儿和老人走路蹒跚。
ex.enText: Babies and aged men totter as they walk.

ex.chText: 他拄着双拐蹒跚而行，来到国王的面前。
ex.enText: With the help of two crutches, he tottered into the King's presence.

synonyms.bx: 指尤因醉酒或患病而摇摇晃晃、跌跌撞撞地行走，好像要跌倒似的。

data.enText: get into your stride
hit (your) stride

data.chText: 进入状态；开始顺利地做某事
data.enText: to begin to do sth with confidence and at a good speed after a slow, uncertain start
put sb off their stride
to make sb take their attention off what they are doing and stop doing it so well
(match sb) stride for stride
to keep doing sth as well as sb else, even though they keep making it harder for you
take sth in your stride
take sth in stride
to accept and deal with sth difficult without letting it worry you too much
without breaking stride
without stopping what you are doing

tr: significant progress (especially in the phrase "make strides")
example: they made big strides in productivity

tr: a step in walking or running
the distance covered by a step
example: he stepped off ten paces from the old tree and began to dig

tr: cover or traverse by taking long steps
example: She strode several miles towards the woods
He strode confidently across the hall

value.def: If you stride somewhere, you walk there with quick, long steps.

example.ex: They were joined by a newcomer who came striding across a field...
example.tran: 一个新来的人大步穿过一片田地，加入到他们的行列。

example.ex: He turned abruptly and strode off down the corridor.
example.tran: 他突然转身，沿走廊大步流星地走了。

value.def: A stride is a long step which you take when you are walking or running.

example.ex: With every stride, runners hit the ground with up to five times their body-weight...
example.tran: 赛跑者每一步落地时对地面的压力最大能达到其体重的 5 倍。

value.def: Someone's stride is their way of walking with long steps.

example.ex: He lengthened his stride to keep up with her.

value.def: If you make strides in something that you are doing, you make rapid progress in it.

example.ex: The country has made enormous strides politically but not economically.
example.tran: 该国在政治上取得了巨大的发展，但经济却跟不上去。

value.def: If you get into your stride or hit your stride, you start to do something easily and confidently, after being slow and uncertain.

example.ex: The campaign is just getting into its stride...
He's still learning and when he hits his stride, he'll be unstoppable.
example.tran: 他仍旧处在学习阶段，一旦驾轻就熟后将势不可挡。

value.tran: 进入状态;开始走上轨道;驾轻就熟

value.def: In British English, if you take a problem or difficulty in your stride, you deal with it calmly and easily. The American expression is take something in stride .

example.ex: Beth was struck by how Naomi took the mistake in her stride.
example.tran: 娜奥米在失误面前表现得处乱不惊，给贝丝留下了深刻印象。

partsOfSpeech.dec: strid 竞争 + e → 走路如竞赛 → 大踏步走
strid 竞争 + ent 具有…性质的，关于…的 → 竞走时发出的声音 → 尖声的，刺耳的
strif 竞争 + e → 竞争；冲突
striv 竞争 + e → 努力；斗争
